turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We’ll hear arguments next in number 71-6852, Lubin against Panish.
Ms. Buckley, you may proceed whenever you’re ready.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Thank you. Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
I am the counsel for Donald Lubin, the petitioner in this case spoke individually and on behalf of the members of his class.

This case first begin a year ago in February, at which time approximately 22 people who were desirers of becoming candidate and the forthcoming elections came to me and we all proceeded to the office of the registrar, the Recorder Registrar in the County of Los Angeles.

Included among these 22 people were men and women, Black and White, most strictly some Freedom Party members but also two members of the Democratic Party, a member of the Republican Party and a member of the American-Independent Party.
They had two things in common, they wanted to be candidates because they had something to say to the electors and they could not afford to pay the filing fees.

Now, there was one other distinction also and that was that most of the people who wanted to become candidates, who are running for a primary position at political office which required them to be a member of the party.

But in county and city elections in California, most of the offices are nonpartisan and therefore, Donald Lubin who wished to run for the office of board of supervisor was running in a general election, not a primary election.
He was not a member of a party for purposes of ballot status.

We filed a writ of mandamus asking the -- both the Recorder Registrar of the County of Los Angeles and the Secretary of State of California to issue nomination papers to these people without the necessity of paying fees.
We were granted a temporary injunction by Judge Cole of the Los Angeles Superior Court and an ultimate writ was set for hearing on March 6.

At that time, Judge Rehnquist sitting in the Los Angeles County Superior Court held that as a matter of law, Bullock applying that as a matter of law, California fees were reasonable and the fact that there was no alternative did not matter under Bullock.
Thereafter, I filed another writ of mandate in the Appellate Court in California, procedure which is an alternate to an appeal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Ms. Buckley, would Judge Weinkie's ruling have been appealable itself to the District Court of Appeal had you chosen to go that route?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, but it would have been meaningless in terms of relief for our clients because we could never have gotten any kind of hearing before the elections would be held.
The only reasonable choice we had was filled by way of writ of mandate to the Appellate Court.
To give them the best opportunity to rule reasonably, we attached a copy of the transcript to the hearing in the lower court.
We were denied with that hearing and we promptly filed a writ of mandate in the Supreme Court.

And again, the transcript of the hearings including Judge Weinkie's statement at page three, to the effect that it appears to the Court that the fees are reasonable as a matter of law was before the Supreme Court and they denied the mandate without a hearing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Under California law, is that necessarily a determination on the merits, their denial without hearing of a petition over extraordinary writ?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: In as much as they had the complete proceedings of the lower court, I know of no case Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: This was not certiorari.
Though I mean, where you are trying to get before, this is a pledge for original writ of mandate, wasn’t it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: But if it presented to the Court, all of the material, which was before the lower court Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And then, their denial without having you sit in is necessarily the decision on the merits, they don’t in their practice occasionally simply deny this disgression.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: I have no knowledge of that Your Honor.
And so, we are now here --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: On the writ of mandate in California is an extraordinary writ as somewhat --

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, isn’t that the answer?
The extraordinary writ the opposite of an appeal isn’t it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
But the particular route that we took is recognized in California law.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Ms. Buckley, while your interrupted let me ask, has the California law with respect to write-ins have been changed since this case developed?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Justice Blackmun, it has not been changed and even if it were, I submit to this Court that write-ins are not a suitable alternative.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You would feel that your case is no weaker if write-ins were permitted.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Without payment of fee.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That is correct.
And, at a later point, I will discuss the differences between the write-in and the position on the Ballot, because it makes a difference --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Were these write-ins identified?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
Since you have raised the question now, I’ll answer it now.
In a write-in situation and in the first place, Donald Lubin had a territory that covered 600,000 people.
As a write-in candidate, he would be required to make his name known to those people not only well enough so that they recognize it on the ballot, but so that they could remember it to write it down.
Now, I cited in my reply brief an instance in California where we had a case of fraud.

A man by the name of Vicenzia was placed on the ballot to take votes away from a man by the name of Valencia and the circumstances around that particular filing made it obvious that there was only one reason for that filing to be done and that was that the voters could even make a mistake between Vicenzia and Valencia and not be able to vote for the man that they wanted to.
How much more difficult would it be for them to remember the man’s name to write it down as the write-in candidate.
Secondly, as a candidate on the ballot, you were entitled to all sorts of things.
Number one, you are entitled the equal time on radio and TV.
Number two, every major newspaper has a practice, in Los Angeles County for instance, of writing articles on the ballot candidates at least once and possibly twice during the campaign.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is the write-in candidate not an established -- write-in candidate not entitled the equal time on television?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: I do not believe so, Your Honor, because until he has in some way established himself as a write-in candidate, he is just running around and telling the people, vote for me.
But, until he complies with the provisions of the code including paying the fee, he is not entitled even to have his vote camp.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but is this the Federal Communications Commission ruling that you are relying and/or just kind of your own judgment of what the law to be.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: I am relying on the fact that as a candidate, I am aware of how difficult it was for even established candidate to get equal time from the stations.

As a practical matter, not all candidates, particularly poll candidates who would be the only people who are write in -- who were being write-in candidates would have even less resources at that command to force, the stations spend to give them equal time and that brings up another point.

If what you offer as an alternative is write-in campaign, you are placing a much greater burden on those people who cannot afford even in many cases the beginning of filing fee and what you are requiring them to do is additional kinds of work that will require more resources than the normal candidate.
You are putting them in an unfair position and the different kind of position than those people who can afford to pay the fee.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How unkind is it, a man has not enough money to put up his filing fee and you say, therefore, he put on to additional burden and not been able to go out and get people to know him.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if I understand you, he could not get there anyhow.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That’s not true Your Honor and I cited an example from our last election where a democratic candidate who -- because of the Storer versus Brown and the filing of this suit was able to get a place on the ballot.
And as a result, he spent -- he would have spent $450.00 in order to be a candidate for Congress.
He did not have that kind of money.
He spent $138.00 of his own money and $40.00 from supporters and he gained 33% of the vote or 17,000 voter.
Now, the alternative here --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I know of a candidate who did not have to go by the proper route but he paid less than $100.00 and elected a senator.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: But, Your Honor, in our state, he would have had to pay for the privilege agreement candidate.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, my whole point is -- that is actually correct.
If the man is broke and hasn’t got any nickel, is there any way under the sun he is ever going to be known to anybody?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
In fact, one of the important things of allowing --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The state of course, did somebody give one.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Justice Marshall?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Am I right?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, you are not and may I say with all due respect, because what will happen is the same thing that happened to our democratic candidate who went around and knocked on doors, and thereby brought more meaning from this.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How many doors did he knockdown?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, he got 16,000 votes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean that he went to 16,000 doors to knock on?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, okay.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Now, with that Your Honor, but we presently have a potential candidate for democratic governor who fortunately does not have to file the form of corpus but he doesn’t have very much money and he is walking the entire state of California thereby getting free publicity both from TV and radio and newspapers.
So it is possible and it is not necessarily going to be the result that somebody who is able to avoid paying a very large fee of $850.00 or $1,000.00 is going to win the election.
But the important thing is that person is not be barred from the political process and I think this is what we are talking about.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But that is entirely different argument from all of these things by that he can get on TV or whatever.
Is your argument that he cannot be discriminated solely because he does not have $850.00?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That and no more -- is that your argument?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but I have been getting questions about the practical result and I agree that the practical results are not an issue here.
What is an issue is whether we can deny people who cannot afford to pay for the privilege of running and opportunity to participate meaningfully in the political process.

And I think that when we look at the facts that the United States which is one of the greatest democracies has a lower voting turnout than many of the other democracies according to the New York Times, then we have to begin to ask why.
And part of why is because in this country, approximately 25% of the people are on a poverty standard of living.

According to the United States, director of a poverty neighborhood legal services and I remember our guidelines very well, $3,500.00 for a family of four and yet the Bureau of Labor Standards says that you need $7,000.00 for a family of four.

Well, if you do not have enough money to feed your family, how are you going to be able to take part in the political process and if it need addition, people who want to represent you and who come from your own class and do not have money either can’t even get on the ballot, then you do not want to vote.

Now, I think so that this Court has made it quite clear that the rights of voters are intertwined with the rights of candidates but I think that it is time for the Court to make the decision that there is a right to be a candidate, to take a forthright position and say that you cannot have elections without candidates.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have mentioned the fact that a very large percentage of the voters do not vote in this country.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you familiar with some of the studies, which have to come to the conclusion for whatever the conclusion maybe would, but one of the reasons is for the lower board of chain out, of the reasons is it is excessively large number of people on the ballots, the long and confusing ballots they must deal with either on the voting machine or on a paper ballot.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I understand and that is very --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would your approach tend to increase the number of candidates running for the public office?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe that there is an alternative and did not -- in my brief, we have discussed the fact that you do need to, -- in some ways make sure that your ballot contains a reasonable number of people and people who are reasonably serious but that can be taken care of by the requirement of petitions and signatures.

New York which is a rival to California in every way handles this matter very well with petitions and they don’t worry about an unwieldy ballot because the very active requiring signatures also means that the candidate has to get out in advance and make himself or herself known to the people and the community.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, because there is another good way or perhaps even another better way, does that looked to a constitutional issue?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, but Your Honor, we are dealing with the very basis of our society.
We are dealing with the political system.

I would like to point out that not only to articles one and two require elected legislature and executives, but that Article 4 Section 4 provides that the United States shall guarantee to every state a republican form of government and the republican form of government means citizens who are entitled to vote.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are you familiar with the Pacific Telephone case Ms. Buckley?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I am not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well then, that is the case where this Court held that the republican form of government clause was not justiciable and was not enforceable by the Courts.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think that this Court has already.

In fact, in San Antonio v. Rodriguez in which they were dealing with an educational problem but you took many takers of decision to deal with the fact that the electoral process is one of the most important processes to our form or government.

And, I only mentioned the constitution as a basis and I am not unaware of the fact that this Court has time after time after time stress the importance of voting that it is in fact one of the explicit rights guaranteed in the constitution and therefore has to be protected in the highest way.
I am merely --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where and when did the Court ever say that?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The right to vote is one of the explicit rights guaranteed in the constitution?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, in Rodriguez, you made the distinction between implicit and explicit and you said that an item such as education and very many other important kinds of rights, maybe very important but were not protected by the constitution because they are not explicit.
And then, you went in and I assumed that you were -- I may have misread your opinion although I did read it several times.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: You then went into the importance of the electoral process to our system.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I would agree that that is important process but of course --

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: And, not only that, but you did what I thought was, from my purposes and my proprieties for this, Your Honor, you did layout very carefully the line of cases in which you dealt with the importance of this right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: And my only -- I am attempting here to point out that the right to be a candidate may one day in the future, in the year 2000, if we use our bookman’s to folders notion of having all of the people come in and vote via two-way television, we may be able to do a way with the necessity of the candidates and representatives, but right now that is our system.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, is there any question about, expect your client is a proper I gather, that is not reading page 10 of the appendix says, his average monthly income during the year 1972 has been the sum of no dollars.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that says it want to, was it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, it was.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Under the penalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That’s never been questioned.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The bonifide of his poverty, is it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
He is a --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Absolute inability to pay this fee of $702.00.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I do not think -- do you need to divest the proposition that there is an explicit issue to use your word --

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- constitutional right to be a candidate for the office in order to make an equal protection claim?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, Your Honor, but --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And suppose, there is not an explicit right to run an unregulated laundry and yet Walter says you can’t regulate some people and not regulate others in an evil eye and an uneven hand.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: But in Turner versus Fouche Your Honor, I think the Court pointed out very well that once you open a position to some people, then you cannot discriminate based on those kinds of factors which are protected by the Fourteenth --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Precisely, whether or not their right to their position is a constitutional right.
Is that your argument?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That is my --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And at least part of it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

The reason I suggested the second part, the question had to do with the question which the members of this Court presented to me that is whether it made a difference whether it was the individuals poverty or that of his group.
And, I took that question to me and I should address myself to the rights of the candidates versus the rights of the supporters or the voters.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Ms. Buckley, you referred to the alternative of nominating petitions?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have you given any thought to what percentage of the people who voted in the last election for example might be inappropriate to United States to determine the number of signatures required?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, if you’re talking about a primary election, I would think that it would not be a percentage of the total who voted, but the total who voted in that particular party because in California, we have four parties, two of which are minor parties.
To demand that they have the same percentage of the vote as those who belong to the majority party would work a great hardship.
They might not even have that many people in their party.
For instance, if you ask for 2% of the population, the American Independent may not even have that many people in that party right now and would require 100% of their membership.

So, I think that you have to schedule it and I think it should be a minimum amount, something say between a thousand and 5000 signatures in a fairly large district and something scaled down in a smaller district.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Assuming you had a requirement for 5,000 petitions in the Los Angeles District other than --

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That would be a statewide Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what would you assume for Los Angeles?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, I believe that there were, for instance, the piece in Freedom Party, they have 30,000 members registered and Los Angeles County of course covers 400 miles.
I covered them all so I am aware of them.
I think that in that case, you might want 1% of 30,000 where I get 3.000 signatures.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What do you think it would cost to obtaining 3,000 signatures?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, I think Your Honor that poor people have learned to walk and I think that they learned to get out and knock on doors.

They may not be able to contribute money and I have documented fairly well the fact that although we now have the opportunity to mark off on our income tax forms, the right to give a dollar to the party of our choice if we belong to a major party.
Only 3% of the people nationwide bothered to check off to give money to their major parties, so for people who may not even be able to file the income tax returns, they cannot give money.
But, they will be go out and knock on doors, they will go out and collect signatures.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you require to have a notary public witness the signatures on nominating petitions?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: We require in California that the person who is collecting the signature gets certified that he has in fact obtained those signatures from the people that he says they were.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that person have to be a notary public?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: On some, Your Honor, they do, but California provides for certification rather than necessity of having a notary public.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Most notaries’ charge fees by doing that.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, except that there is also a provision in the California law that says that notaries may not charge fees for political type of documents.
But again -- so that would be.
I will --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Gaylord.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
There were certain preliminary questions asked.
As I understand this election, this was a true primary.
In California, you have a primary votes for partisan and nonpartisan officers.
As to partisan officers, only those persons registered with the party can vote in that particular primary.
But, the local officers and judicial officers are all nonpartisan and every qualified voter who is registered in the district can vote for one of those offices.
Ever since 1926, if a nonpartisan office, a person gets the majority, he is then and they are elected and then for him, it becomes a general election.

But otherwise, it remains a primary and the one who gets the most votes and the one who gets the second most votes, then is the -- are the two nominated candidates who are -- then go before the voters and the general election in November.

And, if I am correct that this was the Fourth District, that happened then, there were two candidates that got the most and next to the most voters neither one getting majority and one of them was elected in the general election.
The question was asked, what is the status of a denial without opinion by the Supreme Court of a writ of mandate?

There are three Supreme Court cases that definitely hold that the denial by minute order of an application for a writ of mandate is simply a refusal by the state’s Supreme Court to exercise its original jurisdiction and is not an adjudication on the merits.
I merely bring that up because the question was asked.
I am not objecting to the jurisdiction of this Court.
Your Honor, do you want me to -- these citations or shall I get them to the clerk or --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You may hand that to the clerk if you wish.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: I will hand that to the clerk then I -- wait for a moment.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And I take it, Ms. Buckley has copies of her own --

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: I will see that she has a copy.

There was one case before this Court in 1951 where there was a denial by the Court of Appeals without opinion and the Court of Appeals certified that they did deny it on a federal ground and the Court said it had jurisdiction, but in this discretion nevertheless dismissed the case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Your brief proceeds upon the premise that the Court decided the constitutional merit to this case.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: I say I am not objecting the jurisdiction of this Court.

When I originally put back my response petition for writ of certiorari and asked this Court to take jurisdictions frankly I did point have not occurred to me, later I hardly saw that I was in the position to raise the question and I would not raised it but I am merely answering questions over the Court.

On the write-in votes, I would like to stress once more that the requirement for a fee in order to have a write-in vote counted was not put in until 1968, therefore say in 1967, there was a reasonable alternative to having your name on the ballot.

The law was valid then and under the decisions of both this Court and the Supreme Court of California which are cited in our brief, if the fee requirement to write-in votes makes this system unconstitutional, I am not conceding but even if it does, it is the 68th Amendment which is unconstitutional and not the original law which has been in effect since 1913.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is in California law on write-in that is not exactly correct with the -- started and fees growth?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: No, it is not that fee.

The difficulty with the write-in law in California in 1968, they put in a law that both will not be counted for a write-in unless the candidate files a notice at least five days ahead of time that he is a write-in candidate and pays a fee he would have paid to get his name on the ballot.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I understand that, but there are some states where the name, if you leave out the initial, it is no good.
Is that true in California?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: No, I think the rule in California is that if you can definitely ascertain that the name written in is for this particular individual, the vote will be counted for that individual.
I might concede that write-in may be difficult but it has been done.
Mr. Ellis Patterson for example in 1936 lost his bid to be nominated by the Republican Party as the member of the assembly that is the lower house of California.
He distributed pencils having printed thereon, write-in Ellis E. Patterson.
And, the party had the exact name, the exact spelling and he did win the elections.

I also cited that it is very unusual case where a candidate for a judge was defeated in the primary and under the law at that time prior to 1926, the name of the winner was the only one on the ballot and then this defeated judge defeated the winner in the final election by ranking so it can be done.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Suppose the Board of Supervisors of Los Angeles County, how large is board present?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: It’s five-member board.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: All five elected at the (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: All five elected of those supervisorial districts of about 1,400,000 people in each district.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Each on to the separate districts or --

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Each on to the separate districts and --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They do not run at large throughout the county?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: That is correct

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Each runs separate.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: So there would be the voters in a district with a population of 1,400,000.
Incidentally, I take it what Mr. Lubin was running for was to be a supervisor with a salary of over $35,000.00 a year representing almost three times as these many people as a congressman represents.
And, he offers that in Court, if he had any substantial support or whatever, he is sure would have no difficulty in getting the $701.00 for a filing fee.
As the New Mexico Court said which I quoted to the brief, that case now is before this Court I understand.
It does not measure the candidate’s pocket but the amount of his support.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Gaylord, in the 68th Amendment, there is a provision reciting the intention of the legislature that the filing fee shall be used to support the state commission on voting machines or vote tabulating devices.
Has there ever any appropriations that made presumed for that declaration of intent?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: I do not think so.
I do not know.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We don’t have any legal significance in this case?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: No, we are not contending that this fee is necessary to support the election process.
We are contending that it is a test of good faith candidacy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about the first to who has $701.00 or $7,000.00, there is much money, does anybody wanted to try that?
You think judge with the $701.00 that runs at his office is reasonable measure?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: I think it does help.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: It’s not.
I concede it’s not perfect.
It could be that a very well to do man or a rich man would run frivolously because $701.00 means nothing to him but it’s less likely.
It does to keep out to great many frivolous candidates.
Incidentally, a man like that would be less likely to run just as lark besides and that candidate who can do that is --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For instance, I ask that is it our county that you get to find the one without with the $701.00 or the one without?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: That is true but I would say that a man without the $700.00, it is not necessarily barged from putting his name on the ballot if he really has any substantial support.
Now, Ms. Buckley seems to illustrate a man --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the other group know that this man -- you can conceive that with $701.00 putting himself on the ballot would they do support or not.
It does not make some sense of that.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: I agree with that.
I agree that this is not a perfect method but I think the legislatures thinks it is a --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The right of equal protection?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If you think it survived the equal protection.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Yes, I do.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even by this strict scrutiny test?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Yes, I would think so.
It is a reasonable way and what is the alternate?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And reasonably necessary one?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Yes, the only alternate as if I see it is to require a large number of names like 1% or 2% which would be enormous in the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Gaylord, is there anything else that you do other than to put up the money?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Yes, he does have to collect the few signatures, 35 to 40, something like that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is all?
I mean, what is it that you find that he is a responsible person other than money?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Well, the qualifications of a supervisor are merely that he would be a resident of the district.
The charger says for one year before election --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Some of the states --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What else?
Anything else?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: That is the only requirement to be (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I know, the $701.00.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: And to go on the ballot, he must put up.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, there is nothing higher than the money that determines that he is a responsible person, nothing else.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: That is correct.
There is -- I cannot think of any political office like that, I can’t think of any type of civil service examination.
I think that man would be practical.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would the man with $1,500.00 be more responsible than the man with $750.00?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: He might be a little more responsible but --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And so, the more he had, the more responsible it would be?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: That’s correct.
And there is a question of drawing lines, the man who is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I hope that is not everybody’s theory.

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Well, I mean, a man who is 18 on the day of election can vote and yet you cannot say that he is much more learned than the man who is two days younger, but you do have to draw the lines somewhere.
As this Court itself said in Bullock versus Carter, that fee was too high but not all fees are invalid and there becomes a time when the fee becomes too high.
Now, where you draw the line is a difficult question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If we go back to my inquiry about the access so that means the legislate of the corporation of these fees.
How do you answer the suggestion that these fees are nothing more than a revenue raising device?

turn.speaker: edward_h_gaylord
turn.label: Mr. Edward H. Gaylord
turn.text: Well, I would say this, whether there is a specific appropriation or not if the money spent on the election is probably stable -- far greater than the fees collected.
And, if that is true, does it make too much difference that there is a specific appropriation that this particular fund he used for this particular person.
Ms. Buckley mentions in our brief that very few people took advantage of give a dollar to the party of your choice.

Well, it is very easy to see that great many people may not be particularly concerned with a particular political party as a whole, but maybe very much concerned with the particular candidate especially a non-partisan candidate where a person carrying nothing at all about parties would be very interested.
So I do not know think that that is a good illustration.
She also raises in her brief although she hadn’t said it early that there is a provision that you have to get at least 1% of the vote to get a nomination.

That may work some hardship in the case of some very small political parties but in a case of a non-partisan, it is almost inconceivable that somebody would get less 1% of the vote and yet be the second person.

Although all of those voted for, you have to have at least 52 candidates and the very unusual situation to have that so it would be practically impossible for a person to get second in amount of votes in a non-partisan office and not have at least 1%.
And, even if that should happen, it would be practically impossible to the person that got that few votes in the primary would then receive the majority in the general election.
A great deal that Ms. Buckley has said I think is within her brief and has been answered in our brief unless the Court has further questions, that is all I have.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Gaylord.
Ms. Buckley, you have about six minutes left if you want to use them.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: In respect to the question of whether the Supreme Court of the state of California had considered the matter prior to denying it, I would like to draw to your attention the fact that in my experience, the Supreme Court of the state of California generally when presented with the writ of mandate for the first time which it does not believe it has sufficient information to deal with kicks it back to the Appellate Court for decision.
And, that same thing happened in the case of Zapata versus Davidson to 24 California Appellate decisions third 823.
On this very question of the filing fees in the elections that we were talking about, that case were sent to the Appellate Court in April, one month after the Supreme Court had denied us summarily.
And, when presented with a writ of mandate on the exact same question, they sent it to Zapata versus Davidson.
And the Appellate Court determined that the filing fees were in fact unconstitutional based on the Bullock.
So I would like at this time to draw your attention to a case which has not been cited in my brief and that is a Zapata versus Davidson, 24 C A third 283 and that is a 1972 decision.
Now secondly, I would like to discuss very briefly the question of the reasonableness of the California fees.

When counsel leads you to believe that Texas was so different in California, I believe he misstates the question because the Texas fees in some case on state levels were less than those charged in California.

As I read the Texas statute, the real high fees, the $6,000.00 and $8,000.00 were primarily on county levels, but that the state positions ran from $150.00 to $850.00 or $1,000.00 and that is exactly where California is at.
Furthermore, the case of Socialist Party versus all was cited as having legitimized California filing fees but that is a 1909 case.
And, at that time, California had filing fees ranging from $10.00 to $50.00.
It had no relationship to the emoluments of office and --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Though I had that person were a pauper, it would not make any difference of the filing fee were $5.00 or $500.00 or they did not have anything.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor.
But --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In that case, was the plaintiff a pauper?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, I do not believe so, Your Honor.
But the question that was raised was not a US constitutional question, that was a California constitutional question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I will ask somebody about that case.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: But, in that case, the dicta was to the effect that while these fees were reasonable ranging from $10.00 to $50.00, that if the fee structure had been based on the emoluments of office as the present system is that they would have struck it down because such a fee would have no relationship to what it cost to run on election.
It would have no relationship to what it cost to file the papers.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But, that case was designed as a matter of California law was it or --

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, it was, in 1909 and it is the case which my opponent relies upon and which I believe Judge Rehnquist relied upon in saying that California fees were reasonable.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I have the impression from your earlier argument Ms. Buckley that if a fee with $100.00, you would still be here, is that right or not?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I really object to the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You really object to any fee, don’t you?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, if it cost $10.00 to print up the forms for nominating fees, then I think perhaps that could be reasonably explained.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I understood your tradition, that you cannot put a price tag, any candidacy for the purpose of discouraging candidacy.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: You are right, you are right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, so $10.00 would be.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then, there is I thought that your case dependent upon the fact that your client was a pauper.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: It does, he is a pauper.
He cannot afford to pay the fees.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And your argument is not so broad as indicated by my brother Brennan’s questions.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, what I was suggesting, Your Honor, was that -- the case has two basis really and I am suggesting to the Court that we are going to go beyond just the Fourteenth Amendment and beyond the idea that paupers should have the fees removed but we should be looking to the fact that all people have a right to participate in the political process.

Because my client, Mr. Lubin is a pauper, but he is also something else, he has in common with me and with all of you that he is a citizen of the United States and as such has the right to participate.
And, I think that placing any kind of a fee which has no relationship to the actual cost of filing the papers is interfering with the rights of all citizens.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think the state has no interest in preventing if they can having 250 people running for this particular office?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Not by using fees, Your Honor.
Not by using a monetary standards.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, you conceived they have an interest in doing it in some way.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, and I suggest that there is an alternative.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: By the petitioning process.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your broader argument that there is not an equal protection argument is it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: No, I am suggesting to this Court that I am giving you the opportunity if you wish to take it to broaden the scope of what we have done here forward.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what clause of the constitution would you suggest we use to broaden?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, I think, Your Honor, that when we are talking about the right of people to participate in the political system, we are talking about the -- I cannot give you the exact part of the constitution but it seems to me --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Could you just refer to a number or a section?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, what I am suggesting, Your Honor, is that the constitution as a whole protects the political process.
It was designed to assure that we would continue to have a republican form of government that all of the people would be able to participate by voting.
Now, the very provisions that you use to sustain --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How in the world did you say that the constitution was adapted, there was a lot of Blacker people in this country that couldn’t vote.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: You are right, Your Honor, but we may have --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, how could they have been set up to do that if it did not allow it?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, at that point, the problem with our system was that it did not recognized those people as people and that is to the shame of our country.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, but are you going to stand that now to give everybody the right to vote?

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, I believe that for instance, well, we have already given everybody the right to vote via the decisions, which this Court has made, but it did --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They only said in this Court mainly shall not discriminate, so I want you to show me the one that said the right to pull off.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And then, we have got to give that when the right to run (inaudible)

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, I am --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) to find another one.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, I am remembering several cases if I may --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do not read in our brief we are going to fall asleep --

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor, I understand that involves too.
Well, in Oregon versus Mitchell, your brothers Harlan and Brennan both discussed the fact that under --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We are not talking about discussion, I‘m saying, where they said that there was a right to vote or a right to run for the office.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Well, both Brennan and Harlan in Oregon versus Mitchell said that the right to be a candidate was inherent in the right to vote and that it was left out of the Fifteenth Amendment because they assumed it was already there.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I think your time is consumed now Ms. Buckley.

turn.speaker: marguerite_m_buckley
turn.label: Ms. Marguerite M. Buckley
turn.text: Thank you, your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Gaylord.
The case is submitted.
